timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Initial witness depositions begin

timeline.details: Additional witness depositions

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: First interrogation; denied all charges

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Additional witness depositions

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses; no reproaches, firm denials

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire, noting he is strong man and relatively young

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves torture

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Given thumbscrews and rack for about an hour; confessed nothing

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Further rack (quarter hour) then tortillons; surgeon inspected marks on head; continued to deny everything

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks he be held while further witnesses sought; requests surgeon report

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Further witness depositions

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Substitut for procureur fiscal asks for interrogation and confrontations on new evidence

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Additional witness depositions

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Surgeon René le Cerf reports on state after torture; interrogation and confrontations; continued denials

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal suggests original torture not severe enough to count as extraordinaire, asks for repetition

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves question ordinaire

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Given thumbscrews and rack for another hour; still confessed nothing

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal recommends he be renvoyé

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Formal sentence that he be renvoyé from Blamont court

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Second trial: procureur fiscal states he had been tortured but continued to deny; wanted renewed torture or banishment

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Change de Nancy asks for 2 surgeons to inspect 3 scars on head; done same day, marks not diabolical as sensitive to touch

timeline.subject: Claude Henri
timeline.details: Court at Blamont ordered he be renvoyé (second time)

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Hanns alias Febuay
notable_quotes.french: qu'il estoit le cuysenier sur la coste de Repy, qu'il tournoit les Rotz, et chinquoit a boire, et servoit a table ceulx qui y estoient, et ledit Claude Henry luy repartit la dessus qu'il menoit le hautboy aussy gros qu'un chassy de char
notable_quotes.english: that he was the cook on the hill of Repy, that he turned the roasts, and clinked drinks, and served at table those who were there, and Claude Henri replied that he played the oboe as big as a cart chassis
notable_quotes.context: Dispute 18 years earlier between Claude and cousin Didier Aulbry when both guarding animals, calling each other son of a witch

notable_quotes.speaker: Dieudegnon Masson reporting Jeanne femme Demenge Mercier
notable_quotes.french: et que la plus grasse et plus riche l'estoit et la vouloit nommer, toutesfois il ne le fit ad cause qu'il luy fit remonstré qu'il falloit parler de chose certaine, et non a la vollée
notable_quotes.english: and that the fattest and richest was accused and he wanted to name her, however he did not do so because they told him he must speak of certain things, not randomly
notable_quotes.context: Claude's comment when news came that prévôt was looking for someone from Autrepierre

notable_quotes.speaker: Daniel Chaillot (maire of Badonviller) reported by Claude
notable_quotes.french: mais comme il se sentoit homme de bien il ne fit beaucoup d'estat de tel advertissement
notable_quotes.english: but as he felt himself an honest man he did not make much of such a warning

notable_quotes.english: that if they took someone they would hear or see a marvel

notable_quotes.french: une des plus mauvaise teste qu'on scauroit estimer

relationships.evidence_text: witness and Didier Aubertin had bought a horse

economic_context.details: Claude was laboureur and wine trader from Allemaigne. Multiple incidents: (1) Jean Andreu and Didier Aubertin leased horse to Claude but reserved right to take it back if called to pay debts - Claude was indignant and started legal action but desisted. (2) Claude's horses were taken by creditors at one point, preventing him from fetching wine. (3) Dispute over tenure of fields with Aulbry Didier Zabillon. (4) Nicolas Loratte testified Claude wanted lease of moictresse he held. (5) Claude owed curé over 30 francs. (6) Jennon servant only received 2 francs for 9 months service. (7) Adam Bardenat accepted horse from Claude in payment of debt. (8) Economic tensions around wine trading, horse dealing, and grain payments throughout testimony.

legal_context.redress_outcome: Multiple witnesses testified that Claude had been called witch in public without seeking reparation; however, one case (Mengin Masson) was still in litigation at time of witchcraft trial. Claude's failure to seek legal redress in most cases was used as evidence against him.
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Claude held in prison at Blamont; reference to Jeanne femme Demenge Mercier throwing herself from top to bottom of her prison

extraction_metadata.notes: Exceptional case: Claude Henri was tried twice (1614 and 1621) and released both times despite extensive torture. He never confessed despite multiple torture sessions including thumbscrews, rack, and tortillons. His mother was executed as witch ca. 1592. Very detailed trial record with 38 witnesses. Notable for Claude's effective defense strategy, ability to provide alternative explanations, and remarkable resistance to torture. Significant evidence of his refusal to seek legal redress when called witch, which was used against him. Economic tensions around wine trading and horse dealing feature prominently. Case shows importance of social and economic disputes in accusations. Document also includes brief notation about second trial in 1621 where he was again released after torture and inspection of scars.
